Ratings.comment: Professor Chavez was an okay instructor. The course is set up nice with the fact that there are weekly exams instead of midterms and finals, but the material is a lot to learn every week. Also, the "lectures" are just a review of the pre-recorded lectures from other professors that he makes us watch, instead of teaching us the material himself.

Kasulis is an amazing teacher and brilliant scholar. There's a lot of reading in this seminar, but the lectures and discussions were so good, you wanted to be prepared with something good to contribute. Unlike many profs, he's completely down to earth, spending time in office hours discussing issues, always treating my thoughts & work with respect.

My first class with Dr. Kasulis and an amazing experience. He teaches religion and culture from a completely different perspective than many I've seen, those focused on texts and timelines. He teaches from the inside out, creating a bridge between cultures to make Japanese culture and religion familiar. He's the most impressive instructor I've met.

Tons of reading for this class and 4 takehome exams (no final). Got very difficult at the end when he makes you read a book he wrote and doesn't explain it. Overall easy grader and the lectures were semi-interesting. Group project at the end and he doesn't give you much time to prepare. Pretty easy A, don't take if you aren't interested in Buddhism
He wasn't my favorite professor this past semester, but he does genuinely care about the content of the class. Good sense of humor, but sometimes came off as cold and unapproachable.

I took this class as a GE with an already tough schedule. The setup of the class was awful. The amount of readings was excessive, and if you didn't read your in-class midterms would suffer. Recitation (albeit not Kasulis's fault) did not cover any material in class. Lectures were hard to follow and overall the material was not easy.

As a GE course, it is a lot more than you'd like. Set up of the course is pretty simple. Lectures are posted online, but there are assignments due in lecture and Kasulis will call random people as his "attendance." 4 quizzes with study guides based off of lectures. 3 take home exams (essays). Hardest part that uses a textbook is the term paper.

4 quizzes and 3 take home exams (2pg essay) 10% each with a term paper worth 30% of final grade. Even with getting an mid A on every quiz, one 85 can potentially ruin your grade. one quiz average was 70%, but still no curve. Surprisingly difficult for a GEC. He knows a lot but doesn't explain material clearly. Too much reading w/full class sched.

This guy knows so much about asian philosophy but is such a poor teacher of it. TAs suck  too they grade impossibly. Neither are very helpful or good at explaining. Way too hard for a GEC. Unrealistic amount of reading required. Avoid this class unless majoring in philosophy.

Kasulis is a nice guy. He's enthusiastic, makes jokes from time to time, and when he does give them (rarely) has good examples. His TA's though are the opposite. They hardly grade anything, hardly explain anything in recitation, and make a concept more complicated than what it really is. The quizzes are too hard and I can't believe this is a GE.

Kasulis is great! You can tell when he is lecturing that he thoroughly enjoys the subject. Asian Philosophy is a pretty broad spectrum. I understood everything up until the Japanese Philosophy section. There is a lot of work to do for this class, and even though he gives you a study guide for the exams its still not completely clear.

This class sucks.  Kasulius was fine but the TAs were horrible and they were the ones who graded everything.  You think you will do well on exams since we gives you everything but they grade everything impossibly.  There is NO curve at all.  I ended up with a B- and it screwed by GPA.  Wouldn't recommend taking this class.  Way too hard for a GEC.

Kasulis is great. He is extremely enthusiastic. He loves the material and wants you to learn it. If you don't go into the class with a positive attitude, you will probably dislike it. I kept an open mind and didn't have a problem with it. For tests, he gives you a study guide with all possible questions, so it's not tough if you do your work.
Worst professor I had at OSU. Syllabus? Never had one. Grading policy? Rather vague. Willingness to help? Nope. His class was a disaster, and so is he.

This class is really hard to follow. There are a lot of words that you have to just memorize their meaning and even though he is willing to go over stuff it usually doesn't help. He also gets frustrated very easily if he thinks people aren't participating which happens often, as nobody seems to understand what he's even asking.

Dr. Kasulis is awesome. He has so much firsthand knowledge of Japanese culture and religion, it's amazing. His stories about his interactions with various Buddhist monks were always entertaining. Class wasn't too difficult, for a graduate level class, though there were only 4 grades, so each was super important
If you're interested in Religious Studies at all (especially Buddhism) Dr. Kasulis is an amazing resource. Funny and extremely well versed, and it's easy to get a good grade if you pay attention.

Terrible class I thought it was going to be much more interesting and fun but instead it was boring as hell.  Nothing he taught made any sense.  If you are good at memorization then you should take it but i would stay away from this class

Terrible, Terrible class. DO NOT TAKE Asian Philosophies.  The class is the most boring class ever.  If you enjoy mindless BS philosophy then by all means take it.  But take my word for it.  This is the WORST GEC to take ever unless you're a philosophy major.  STAY AWAY!!!!

I loved this class. Kasulis is extremely informative and knows his stuff. I would love to take another course with him again. Grading is done by TA's but, the material is easy and they go over it word for word. Lectures were great and interesting.

Good professor--really knew his material.  Very friendly and funny.  His lectures could get a little boring at times (especially hard to stay awake at 8:30 am) but I would take him again.  Easy exams--pure memorization.
It was a fun class. He's easy going for lectures. TAs do the grading.

Tom Kasulis is a great teacher. I learned so much in his class. He has an intense understanding of Japanese people and thier religions. His teaching style is woven with great stories that are humourous and relevant. Take your study guides seriously and you will do well and learn a lot. This is a class that you can actually enjoy.

Kasuils is a great professor. I learned a lot about many different religions. When he would talk about Shinto (his specialty) you can tell he is passionate about what he teaches. He was extremely helpful outside the class room. He is there if you approach him but if you don't you won't feel as if he was helpful. P.S He has great stories! :)

He is genuinely interested in conveying the course information & gist. Lectures were interesting and helpful for the most part. There are very few grades so each is crucial. I'd recommend the course to anyone with one caveat: start memorizing the vocabulary right away and the course will be very enjoyable. I was very glad I took the couse from tom.
Awesome teacher, fascinating subject. Pay attention in class and be sure to study the terms he says will appear on the tests and you should do fine.

I didn't know Japanese religions were interesting until I took this course. Kasulis' philosophy background shows in his approach, which IMO is lucid, thorough, engaging... If you enjoy a deep understanding of other cultures, take this prof. Not too hard, not too easy.
No Comments
pretty good lecturer; sometimes he seems to make stuff up; easy midterms; not a help at all outside of class
Interesting class, very easy. Professor is friendly, helpful, and most importantly, is a native English speaker.
Very interesting course, engaging professor.

Pat Sieber is really knowledgeable in her subject, though it comes across sometimes very boring and oftentimes unorganized. For the most part, it seems as if she knows so much that when she comes into class, it jumps around from topic to topic because she did not come in with anything SPECIFIC to talk about, or gets sidetracked on questions easily.

She is ok. If you have some literature foundation left from high school you should do fine. Her lectures are boring and I literally just go to her class to do homework for other classes. The assignments are not too hard and she is a very easy going grader.
A very knowledgeable teacher who goes to great lengths to help students. Amount of class work and grading are both fair.

You will like her if you find the topics interesting; if not, she might not make them interesting for you. I found her to be very easy to talk with, a little vague on assignments but very helpful if you ask in person for clarification. A super cool lady!

Clearly very knowledgeable, yet you'll forget it while listening to her talk and talk and ultimately fail to get the information across properly. She gets plenty of credit for being fairly nice, though.

Good teacher, lecture can be dull at times, but very knowledgeable and inviting for discussion. BTW, she is not in religious studies, she is a Chinese professor who teaches in Chinese or EALL. Grading is fair, if you talk and study what she goes over in class you should get an A
She's cool.

Probably the worst class you are forced to go to because of participation points. Gives no time for assignments. Lectures are dull and I wrote down nothing in 10 weeks. Readings are very strange and also irrelevant. Avoid this one.

Dr. Weiner was my first professor at OSU and I couldn't have asked for a better start to my time at OSU. The class is structured to allow students to succeed and the lectures and easy to understand while being engaging. I heavily recommend this class for the GE Race, Ethnicity and Gender Diversity.

Great professor and a very easy class. There are no exams, just a few 3-5 page papers along with the normal reflection posts and 8-10 question quizzes on Canvas. He is extremely caring and understanding if you have to miss class and is open to helping you in circumstances outside of the class even if you just want to talk. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

I would 100% recommend taking a class with Professor Dew. This class is very discussion-based, which was a refreshing break from the typical lecture-heavy format. His teaching skills are amazing, and he knows how to engage the class and get everyone excited about the material we were reading. Put in the effort, and you will earn an A.

Second class I have taken with Dew. He is hilarious -- attendance not mandatory, but always had a good time when I showed up. Low key insane amount of reading expectations though. I liked the readings (they were always interesting), but you can get by skimming the books. Easy exams / projects.
Very caring and tries to make class discussions engaging. Supportive outside of class. Workload is not too bad and is a fairly easy grader. Wonderful professor overall!

He was great at picking insightful texts and getting us involved in the discussions. The class is entirely discussion based from readings we do for homework, but the readings are very enjoyable. Other than that, there are just three papers which you can be creative with and share your own opinions with. Definitely recommend!

Professor Dew was a really good professor this spring. I had him for African American Lit and while I didn't know what to expect in this class at first, he made it fun and insightful. He definetely talks more than her should and sometimes interrupts the discussion but it's not intentional. He does a good job leading and only assigned 3 essays
Professor Dew is amazing as both an academic and a person. My only complaint is that the Carmen for the course is a bit confusing.

Dr. Dew is super passionate, and it reflects in his teaching. The class is pretty much all discussion, but not graded discussion. The readings can be kind of a lot, but class is effective at clearing up confusion. 

Grading is really lenient, except maybe the midterm and final, but those don't count for much compared to most other courses.

Professor Dew is awesome. He is enthusiastic about his classes.b Lecture and discussion based which were well done and engaging. Really responsive to emails, easy to reach, flexible and understanding. Do the work, give your best effort, and you will get a good grade. He is currently an OSU prof, visiting prof at Kenyon where I took his class.

Spencer is easily my favorite professor I have had at OSU. He is definitely picky with his grading, but his lectures are always extremely helpful, and he is easy to access outside of class. The class itself is based off of 4 papers, and since he is a picky grader, they can be intimidating, but the class is so interesting and definitely worth taking

Lectures were pretty boring, not going to lie. But Prof. Dew is a good professor in discussions about the book and making you understand it better. In order to do well in this class you will have to read, in my section we read about 5 novels and wrote 4 essays. Only graded by these essays and discussion board posts.

Interesting class. It was his first time teaching it at OSU and it was not what I was expecting, but in a good way. Learned a lot you wouldn't normally learn in this type of intro class. Confusing in class, but great convos in office hours. Easy grading, pretty lax with it too. Discussion boards, one quiz, and a hefty research project for grades.

The guy is interesting and clearly very smart, but something about him is a little annoying to me. He likes to hear himself talk. Never answers questions helpfully, just goes off on tangents. Grading was confusing, couple tests and a project. The way he built the class was great though. Not your average comparative religion class--I learned a lot.

Doctor Weiner is one of my favorite professors at OSU. He truly cares about his students and has an absolute wealth of knowledge about religion and world history. There are a lot of "assigned" readings for this class but honestly you do not have to read them as long as you make sure to reference lectures in your papers you will get good grades.
Overall a great professor. Nothing to really complain about and he definitely cares about his students. Class was set up well and everything was communicated clearly.
Professor Weiner was a good lecturer, and the class is set up super easy. Interesting ideas are discussed, and was an easy credit for the race, gender, and diversity GE. Really nice guy.

Professor Weiner was one of my favorite teachers that I have had so far during college. He really loves what he teaches about which makes lectures so much more interesting. There are weekly discussion posts and a few essays, but as long as you take them seriously, you will have no problem getting a good grade.

I took this class to fulfill my "race, ethnicity, and gender diversity" GE requirement. This will be one of the easiest classes on your schedule. Plenty of different grades: 2 light papers, weekly reflection posts, TopHat attendance codes, 5-6 online quizzes, and 3 "case studies" from chosen lecture topics. Submit everything and you will get an A.

Dr. Weiner is undoubtedly the best professor I have  had in my life. Super passionate about what he teaches, and left every class feeling smarter. Would take this class again in a heartbeat. 

If it matters to you, the class is an easy A. No tests, quizzes, midterm or final. Graded on 2 papers + 1 project, but those are graded pretty light.

Professor Weiner is a really good professor who cares about all of his students. While attendance is mandatory, he is very understanding and willing to bend the rules if you communicate with him. He prioritizes giving good feedback and you can tell he's genuinely passionate about what he teaches.

Professor Weiner really cares for his students. His content can be challenging to understand but he makes it manageable for all students. Mix of discussion posts and a few papers but nothing to worry about if you space the work out. Great guy, good option for GE requirement.

One of my favorite professors, he offers really interesting topics for discussion. Course is challenging, but hardly impossible. It's asynchronous, so don't worry about logging on at a specific time unless you want to. Overall, super smart and knowledgeable guy, committed to making the material accessible. Would definitely take this class again!
Amazing course! Amazing professor! You will learn a lot and actually enjoy it the whole time!! Awesome.
